title: Relates to the humane treatment of animals
summary: Relates to the humane treatment of animals by students in schools, in connection with school sponsored events or activities and experimental studies in laboratories.

       Introduced  by  Sen.  DUANE  -- read twice and ordered printed, and when
         printed to be committed to the Committee on Education

       AN ACT to amend the education law, in relation to the  humane  treatment
         of animals

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1.  Subdivision 4 of section 809  of  the  education  law,  as
    2  amended  by  chapter  320  of  the  laws  of 2010, is amended to read as
    3  follows:
    4    4. Dissection of animals. Any student expressing a moral or  religious
    5  objection  to  the  performance  or  witnessing  of the dissection of an
    6  animal, either wholly or in part, shall be provided the  opportunity  to
    7  undertake  and complete an alternative project that shall be approved by
    8  such student's  teacher;  provided,  however,  that  such  objection  is
    9  substantiated  in  writing  by  the  student's parent or legal guardian.
   10  Students who perform alternative projects who do not perform or  witness
   11  the dissection of animals shall not be penalized. The board of education
   12  or  trustees of a school district shall develop a policy to give reason-
   13  able notice to all students enrolled  in  a  course  that  includes  the
   14  dissection  of  an animal and students' parents or legal guardians about
   15  their rights under this subdivision. Such notice shall be made available
   16  upon request at the school  and  distributed  to  parents  and  students
   17  enrolled  in  a  course  that  includes  dissection at least once at the
   18  beginning of the school  year  PRIOR  TO  THE  USE  OF  ANY  ANIMAL  FOR
   19  DISSECTION.
   20    S  2.  Subdivisions  5  and  6 of section 809 of the education law, as
   21  amended by chapter 542 of the laws of 1994, are amended and a new subdi-
   22  vision 7 is added to read as follows:
   23    5. Treatment of live vertebrate animals. a. Except as provided for  in
   24  this  subdivision,  no school district, school principal, administrator,
   25  or teacher shall require or permit the performance of a lesson or exper-

    1  imental study on a live vertebrate animal in any such school  or  during
    2  any  activity conducted under the auspices of such school whether or not
    3  the activity takes place on the premises  of  such  school  [where  such
    4  lesson  or  experimental  study employs: (i) micro-organisms which cause
    5  disease in humans or  animals,  (ii)  ionizing  radiation,  (iii)  known
    6  cancer  producing  agents,  (iv)  chemicals  at  toxic levels, (v) drugs
    7  producing pain or deformity, (vi) severe extremes of temperature,  (vii)
    8  electric or other shock, (viii) excessive noise, (ix) noxious fumes, (x)
    9  exercise  to  exhaustion,  (xi)  overcrowding, (xii) paralysis by muscle
   10  relaxants or other means, (xiii) deprivation or excess of food, water or
   11  other essential nutrients, (xiv) surgery or other  invasive  procedures,
   12  (xv) other extreme stimuli, or (xvi) termination of life].
   13    b.  [Notwithstanding  any  inconsistent provision of this section, the
   14  commissioner may, upon the submission of a written program  plan,  issue
   15  to  such  school  a  written  waiver  of  such restrictions for students
   16  subject to the following provisions: (i) the student shall be  in  grade
   17  ten,  eleven,  or twelve; and (ii) the student shall be under the super-
   18  vision of one or more teachers  certified  in  science;  and  (iii)  the
   19  student shall be pursuing an accelerated course of study in the sciences
   20  as  defined  by  the  commissioner  in preparation for taking a state or
   21  national advanced placement examination. The commissioner shall issue  a
   22  waiver  of  such  restrictions  for  any  teacher  certified  in science
   23  instructing such student. The written program plan  shall  include,  but
   24  not  be  limited  to: (i) the educational basis for requesting a waiver;
   25  (ii) the objective of the lesson or experiment; (iii)  the  methods  and
   26  techniques  to  be  used; and (iv) any other information required by the
   27  commissioner.] LIVE VERTEBRATES  ARE  DEFINED  AS  ANY  LIVE,  NON-HUMAN
   28  VERTEBRATE,  MAMMALIAN  EMBRYO  OR  FETUS,  BIRD AND REPTILE EGGS WITHIN
   29  THREE DAYS (SEVENTY-TWO HOURS) OF HATCHING, AND ALL OTHER VERTEBRATES AT
   30  HATCHING OR BIRTH. EXCLUDED FROM THE ABOVE PROVISIONS ARE:
   31    (I) LESSONS  AND  EXPERIMENTAL  STUDIES  INVOLVING  ANIMALS  IN  THEIR
   32  NATURAL  ENVIRONMENT  THAT  ARE  NON-INVASIVE  AND NON-INTRUSIVE STUDIES
   33  (I.E. OBSERVATIONAL, BEHAVIORAL) THAT DO NOT AFFECT AN  ANIMAL'S  HEALTH
   34  OR  WELL-BEING  BY  CAUSING  STRESS, DISCOMFORT OR PAIN AND IN WHICH THE
   35  STUDENT WILL HAVE NO PHYSICAL CONTACT WITH THE ANIMAL; OR
   36    (II) LESSONS AND EXPERIMENTAL STUDIES BEING CONDUCTED IN A  REGISTERED
   37  INSTITUTION  OR  LABORATORY WHERE ANIMAL EXPERIMENTATION IS TAKING PLACE
   38  AND IN WHICH THE STUDENT WILL HAVE NO PHYSICAL CONTACT WITH THE  ANIMAL;
   39  AND  THE  STUDENT  WORKS  ONLY  WITH NON-LIVING MATERIAL (E.G.   TISSUE,
   40  BLOOD) THAT HAS BEEN SUPPLIED TO THE STUDENT BY THE  SUPERVISING  SCIEN-
   41  TIST; AND THE ANIMAL INVOLVED IS SACRIFICED FOR A PURPOSE OTHER THAN THE
   42  RESEARCH BEING CONDUCTED BY THE STUDENT.
   43    ALL  OF THE ABOVEMENTIONED LESSONS, AND EXPERIMENTAL STUDIES MUST HAVE
   44  A NON-HUMAN VERTEBRATE ANIMAL EXCEPTION FORM COMPLETED BY THE  STUDENT'S
   45  SUPERVISING SCIENTIST WHICH ATTESTS TO COMPLIANCE WITH THIS SUBDIVISION.
   46  SUCH  FORMS  SHALL  BE  SENT BY THE STUDENT'S SCHOOL TO THE COMMISSIONER
   47  UPON COMMENCEMENT OF THE LESSONS OR EXPERIMENTAL STUDIES.
   48    6. Report. [On or before the first day of January next succeeding  the
   49  effective  date  of  this  amended  section, the] THE commissioner shall
   50  annually submit a report to the governor and the legislature which shall
   51  include, but not be limited to, the  [number  of  written  program  plan
   52  proposals  submitted  by schools and the number of such proposals subse-
   53  quently approved by the commissioner. In those  cases  where  a  program
   54  plan  proposal has been approved by the commissioner, such plan shall be
   55  appended to and become a part of the commissioner's annual report]  NON-

       S. 1302                             3

    1  HUMAN  VERTEBRATE  EXCEPTION  FORMS  COMPLETED  BY STUDENTS' SUPERVISING
    2  SCIENTIST AND SUBMITTED TO THE COMMISSIONER BY THEIR SCHOOLS.
    3    7.  THE  COMMISSIONER  SHALL PROMULGATE SUCH RULES AND REGULATIONS AND
    4  DEVELOP SUCH FORMS AS ARE NECESSARY TO EFFECTUATE THE PURPOSES  OF  THIS
    5  SECTION.
    6    S  3.  This act shall take effect on the first of July next succeeding
    7  the date on which it shall have become a law; provided, however, that if
    8  chapter 320 of the laws of 2010 shall not  have  taken  effect  by  such
    9  effective  date,  then  section one of this act shall take effect on the
   10  same date and in the same manner as chapter 320 of the laws of 2010,  as
   11  amended, takes effect.
